126.00.text: I first got interested in stained glass

128.00.text: when I was traveling with my mom;

130.00.text: I was about 10 years old, and I was traveling with her

134.00.text: on a train to Edinburgh in Scotland,

137.00.text: and we stopped into a bookstore.

139.00.text: I remember seeing this big reference book,

141.00.text: The Rose Windows of the World,

146.00.text: of all over the world-- of Notre Dame

149.00.text: and all the rose windows from everywhere,

151.00.text: and it was psychedelic, it was captivating,

153.00.text: and I remember just looking at it

155.00.text: and just thinking this is so cool.

156.00.text: And I'm realizing that people did this in the Middle Ages,

163.00.text: just putting so much time and energy

222.00.text: The history of stained glass has evolved very, very little.

226.00.text: It's basically, the way I make it here is the way it's always

230.00.text: pretty much been made, you know, except for I don't have

233.00.text: my soldering iron heating up in a bed of coals.

246.00.text: and then it went through kind of a slump,

249.00.text: and then it reared its head again in the 1970s

251.00.text: in the form of kind of kitschness and craftiness

255.00.text: and I think that's given it a bad name.

257.00.text: Stained glass has been trying to escape

259.00.text: from this kind of suncatcher, rainbow,

386.00.text: a lot of lead crystal, it has a lot of refractive properties,

391.00.text: It has air bubbles and various different striations in it.

395.00.text: It's never the same; no two pieces are ever the same.

398.00.text: It's not uniform, so the thickness is different,

401.00.text: and even from the same sheet, the color varies.

403.00.text: That's what I love about working with glass is,

406.00.text: you're actually using light as a tool, light is one of our tools.
